title: New Udog Cento shoes use dial closures and a patented strap tensioning system
content:
Cyclist
New Udog Cento shoes use dial closures and a patented strap tensioning system

Udog has launched its latest road shoe, the Cento. It’s the Italian brand’s first shoe with dial closures, where it has previously focussed on lace-up shoe designs, and it claims that the new shoe provides the precise, locked-in feel that racers demand. The two dials are combined with a patented lace-based tensioning system, which Udog says provides more even pressure distribution over the foot.

Udog’s principal is Alberto Fonte, whose 16 years in the cycling industry have included stints at Fizik and before that at Pinarello and Kask. What does Udog mean? It’s short for ‘underdog’, and is a reference to the brand’s claim that we’re all underdogs in life.

Patented closure system

Rather than join up with Boa, which tends to be the default dial closure for the majority of cycling shoes, Udog has developed its own dial system, called Micro Twist. It has also positioned the front dial on the top of the shoe, rather than the more normal outer side.

Udog says that the Micro Twist’s 30mm diameter rubber-edged grip offers easier adjustment when racing, while its slim 10mm depth increases its aero efficiency.

The front dial uses a wire, which works with patented woven laces that lie flat on the shoe. Udog says that these provide a greater surface area than an all-wire based tensioning system, which improves pressure distribution over the top and sides of the foot. It claims that this helps to eliminate pressure points in the upper.

There are fabric lace guides for the front loop of the tensioning wire, which it says also help to avoid pressure hot spots. It’s an upgrade of the Tension Wrap System lace arrangement used in Udog’s existing Tensione and Distanza shoes.

Udog also claims that the positioning of the upper dial low on the side of the shoe provides improved heel retention over a wide range of foot sizes.  

270g claimed weight per shoe

The shoe itself is made from laser-perforated microfibre, which Udog says is lightweight and soft, allowing the foot to move around a little for comfort, while TPU reinforcement ensures the secure fit needed for power delivery. Udog claims its roomy toe box and deep heel cup help too.

As you’d expect, there’s a carbon composite sole unit. Udog rates this at 11 on its stiffness index – as with most shoe vendors, it doesn’t say what this represents or what its maximum stiffness number can be. It says that there’s wide cleat adjustability fore and aft from its titanium alloy cleat nuts.

Udog claims a 270g weight per shoe in size 42, which is up there with the best cycling shoes. The Cento is non-gender specific and available in 11 whole sizes from 38 to 48. It’s priced at £260 / $325 / €295 and will ship from March 2024.

  • Buy the Udog Cento shoes now from Udog (£256)
